description.heading: 1. Measurement of SSF
description.p: The spectral separation factor SSF of the ink was calculated by using the data of the recorded spectrum of an ink solution and comparing the maximum absorbance to the absorbance at a reference wavelength. The reference wavelength chosen for a magenta inkjet ink was 650 nm.

The absorbance was determined in transmission with a Shimadzu UV-2101 PC double beam-spectrophotometer. The ink was diluted with ethyl acetate to have a pigment concentration of 0.005%. A spectrophotometric measurement of the UV-VIS-NIR absorption spectrum of the diluted ink was performed in transmission-mode with a double beam-spectrophotometer using the settings of Table 3. Quartz cells with a path length of 10 mm were used and ethyl acetate was chosen as a blank. Table 3
ModeAbsorbance
Wavelength range240-900 nm
Slit width2.0 nm
Scan interval1.0 nm
Scan speedFast (1165 nm/min)
Detectorphoto-multiplier(UV-VIS)
Efficient pigment inkjet inks exhibiting a narrow absorption spectrum and a high maximum absorbance have a value for SSF of at least 30.
description.heading: 2. Dispersion stability
description.p: The dispersion stability was evaluated by comparing the SSF before and after a heat treatment of one week at 80°C. Pigmented inkjet inks exhibiting good dispersion stability have a SSF after heat treatment still larger than 30 and a loss in SSF of less than 35%.
description.heading: 3. Average particle size
description.p: The average particle size of pigment particles in inkjet ink was determined with a Brookhaven Instruments Particle Sizer BI90plus based upon the principle of dynamic light scattering. The ink or dispersion was diluted with ethyl acetate to a pigment concentration of 0.002 wt%. The measurement settings of the BI90plus were: 5 runs at 23°C, angle of 90°, wavelength of 635 nm and graphics = correction function.

For good ink jet characteristics (jetting characteristics and print quality) the average particle size of the dispersed particles is below 200 nm, preferably about 100 nm. The inkjet ink is considered to be a stable pigment dispersion if the particle size remains below 200 nm after heat treatment of 7 days at 80°C.
description.heading: 4. Viscosity
description.p: The viscosity of the inkjet inks was measured using a Brookfield DV-II+ viscometer at 25°C and shear rate of 15 RPM.
This example illustrates the synthesis of the quinacridone derivatives in accordance with present invention.
description.heading: Synthesis of quinacridone derivative QAD-1
description.p: The quinacridone derivative QAD-1 is represented by the formula:
Synthesis of the dispersion synergist QAD-1 was accomplished according to the following synthesis scheme:

25 g (0.1 mol) of diethyl-5-hydroxymethyl)isophthalate was dissolved in a mixture of 100 mL of methylenechloride and 0.3 g dimethylacetamide (catalyst). 19.6 g (0.165 mol) of thionylchloride was added drop wise and the mixture was stirred during the night. After this period, the mixture was cooled in an ice bath and 150 mL of ethanol was added. While the methylenechloride was evaporated under reduced pressure a solid appeared. This solid product QA-1 was filtered and washed with a small volume of ethanol. The yield was 86%.

31.0 g (0.1 mol) of dried pigment PV19 in 500 mL dimethylsulfoxide was dissolved by the addition of 22.44 g (0.2 mol) potassium tert-butoxide. The blue solution was heated to about 70°C and 27.1 g (0.1 mol) of compound QA-1 was added. The alkylation-step was done after 2 hours and the product was hydrolyzed by the addition of 72.4 g (0.4 mol) sodiummethylate and 200ml of water. After 1 hour the mixture was cooled to about 50°C and the pigment was precipitated with acetone (about 1000 mL). The precipitate was filtered and washed with acetone. This solid product was dissolved in 1000 mL of water and the acid form was precipitated by the addition of an excess of concentrated hydrochloric acid. The dispersion synergist QAD-1 was filtered and washed with water. The yield was 85%.
description.heading: Synthesis of quinacridone derivative QAD-2
description.p: The quinacridone derivative QAD-2 is represented by the formula:
Synthesis of the dispersion synergist QAD-2 was accomplished according to the following synthesis scheme:

34.0 g (0.1 mol) of dried pigment PR122 in 500 mL dimethylsulfoxide was dissolved by the addition of 22.44 g (0.2 mol) potassium tert-butoxide. The blue solution was heated to about 70°C and 27.1 g (0.1 mol) of compound QA-1 was added. The alkylation-step was done after 2 hours and the product was hydrolyzed by the addition of 72.4 g (0.4 mol) sodium methylate and 200 mL of water. After 1 hour the mixture was cooled to about 50°C and the product was precipitated with acetone (about 1000 mL). The precipitate was filtered and washed with acetone. The solid product was dissolved in 1000 mL of water and the acid form was precipitated by the addition of an excess of concentrated hydrochloric acid. The dispersion synergist QAD-2 was filtered and washed with acetone. The yield was 85%.
description.heading: Synthesis of quinacridone derivative QAD-3
description.p: The quinacridone derivative QAD-3 is represented by the formula:
Synthesis of the dispersion synergist QAD-3 was accomplished according to the following synthesis scheme:

38.1 g (0.1 mol) of dried pigment PR202 in 130 gram dimethylsulfoxide was dissolved by the addition of 23 g (0.205 mol) potassium tert-butoxide. The blue-green solution was heated to about 110°C for 1 hour. Then the mixture was cooled till 40°C, and 25.5 g (0.105 mol) of compound QA-2 was added. The alkylation-step was done after 4 hours. The product was hydrolyzed by the addition of 400 ml of water and 19.5 gram Potassium hydroxide 86% (0.3 mol) after 4 hours heating at 60°C. Then 75 ml concentrated hydrochloric acid (0.9 mol) was added to the mixture. The dispersion synergist QAD-3 was filtered and washed with water. The yield was 100 %.
Synthesis of dimethyl-(5-chloromethyl)isophthalate (QA-2) was accomplished according to the following synthesis scheme:

22.4 g (0.1 mol) of dimethyl-(5-hydroxymethyl)isophthalate (QAOH-2) was dissolved in a mixture of 100 mL of Toluene and 0.2 g dimethylacetamide (catalyst). 15.4 g (0.13 mol) of thionylchloride was added drop wise and the mixture was stirred during 4 hour at 40°C. After this period, the mixture was cooled in an ice bath and 50 mL of methanol was added. This solid product QA-2 was filtered and washed with a small volume of methanol. The yield was 58%.
Synthesis of dimethyl-(5-hydroxymethyl)isophthalate QOAH-2 was accomplished according to the following synthesis scheme:

25.2 g (0.1 mol) of trimethyl 1,3,5 benzenetricarboxylate was dissolved in 85 mL of methyl acetate at 50°C. 40.5 ml (0.08 mol) lithiumborohydride 2.0 M in THF was added drop wise and the mixture was stirred during 3 hour at 50°C. After this period 5.3 gram acetic acid (0.088 mol) and 3 mL water were added. The methyl acetate and THF were evaporated, 50 ml water and 50 ml n-hexane were added. The product QAOH-2 was filtered and washed with a small volume water and n-hexane. The yield was 63%.
description.heading: Synthesis of quinacridone derivative QAD-2N
description.p: Synthesis of the dispersion synergist QAD-2N was accomplished according to the following synthesis scheme:

51.9 g (0.1 mol) of the dispersion synergist QAD-2 was suspended in a mixture of 200 mL methanol, 200 mL methylenechloride and 100 mL water. 74.25 (0.25 mol) of N,N-dimethyl-N-octadecylamine was added and the mixture was stirred during 3 days at room temperature. After 3 days the methylenechloride was evaporated under vacuum and the dispersion synergist QAD-2N was filtered and washed with a mixture of water / methanol (1/1). The yield was 60%.

This example illustrates that stable pigment dispersions of quinacridone pigments for use in solvent based ink-jet inks were obtained when a quinacridone derivative containing two carboxylic acid groups was used as dispersion synergist.
description.heading: Synthesis of comparative dispersion synergist SYN-1
description.p: The compound SYN-1 having a quinacridone structure but a sulfonic acid salt group was used as a comparative dispersion synergist.
Synthesis of the dispersion synergist SYN-1 was accomplished according to the following synthesis scheme:

31.2 g (0.1 mol) of the pigment PV19 in 210 mL dimethylsulfoxide was heated to about 80°C. The magenta suspension was dissolved by addition of 22.44 g (0.2 mol) of potassium tert-butoxide.13.6 g (0.1 mol) of 1,4-butanesultone and 1.7 g (0.01 mol) of potassium iodide are added to the blue solution and the mixture was heated during 4 hours. After cooling down the dispersion synergist SYN-1 was precipitated by adding 210 mL of methanol. The synergist was filtered and washed with methanol. The yield was 60%.
description.heading: Synthesis of comparative dispersion synergist SYN-2
description.p: The compound SYN-2 having a quinacridone structure but a sulfonic acid salt group was used as a comparative dispersion synergist.
Synthesis of the dispersion synergist SYN-2 was accomplished according to the following synthesis scheme:

A solution of 48.7 g (0.1 mol) of dispersion synergist SYN-1 in 500 mL water was heated to about 70°C. 63 g (0.1 mol) of dimethyl dioctadecyl ammonium bromide was added to this solution and after 15 minutes a precipitate appeared. The mixture was cooled to room temperature and the precipitate was filtered and washed with methanol. The yield was 70%.
description.heading: Synthesis of comparative dispersion synergist SYN-3
description.p: The compound SYN-3 having a quinacridone structure but a sulfonic acid salt group was used as a comparative dispersion synergist.
Synthesis of the dispersion synergist SYN-3 was accomplished according to the following synthesis scheme:

A solution of 48.7 g (0.1 mol) of dispersion synergist SYN-1 in 500 mL water was heated to about 70°C. 52.2 g (0.1 mol) of tridodecylamine was added and the mixture was heated during 15 minutes. After this period the mixture was cooled to room temperature and 41.6 mL (0.5 mol) of hydrochloric acid was added drop wise. The product was precipitated as an oil. During the night the oil was converted in a solid product. This synergist was filtered and washed with water. The yield was 61%.
description.heading: Synthesis of comparative dispersion synergist SYN-4
description.p: The compound SYN-4 having a quinacridone structure but with a hydroxyethyl group was used as a comparative dispersion synergist.
description.heading: Synthesis scheme of SYN-4:
description.p: 25 g (80 mmol) PV19 was suspended in 200 mL DMSO. 17.9 g (160 mmol) KOtBu was added and the suspension was heated to 70°C. 21.64 g (104 mmol) 2-(2-bromoethoxy)-tetrahydro-2H-pyran was added and the reaction was allowed to continue for 3 hours at 70°C. After cooling down to room temperature, 300 mL of water is added. The crude intermediate was isolated by filtration, washed with water and dried. The crude intermediate was suspended in 500 mL acetone. 8.0 mL HCl (conc.) was added and the reaction was allowed to continue for 1 hour at room temperature. N-hydroxyethyl-quinacridone was isolated by filtration, washed with acetone, re-suspended in acetone, again isolated by filtration and dried. The yield was 92 %.
description.heading: Synthesis of comparative dispersion synergist SYN-5
description.p: The compound SYN-5 having a quinacridone structure but substituted by only one carboxylic acid group was used as a comparative dispersion synergist
Synthesis of the dispersion synergist SYN-5 was accomplished according to the following synthesis scheme:

34 g (0.1 mol) of the pigment PR122 in 500 mL dimethylsulfoxide was dissolved by addition of 22.44 g (0.2 mol) of potassium tert-butoxide. The blue solution was heated to about 70°C and 22.8 g (0.1 mol) of methyl-4-(bromomethyl)benzoate was added. The mixture was cooled after 2 hours and the product was precipitated, filtered and washed with methanol. The yield was 65%.

Formation of the dispersion synergist SYN-5 was accomplished by hydrolization of compound QA-3. This reaction takes place during a reflux of 48.8 g (0.1 mol) of compound QA-3 in a mixture of ethanol and 50 mL (0.5 mol) of 29% sodium hydroxide solution. After 1 hour the mixture was cooled down, the precipitate was filtered and washed with water. The precipitate was taken up in 1 L of water and the acid form was made by the addition of 50 mL (0.6 mol) of concentrated hydrochloric acid. The dispersion synergist SYN-5 was filtered and washed with water and ethanol. The yield was 71%.

All inkjet inks were prepared in the same manner to obtain a composition as described in Table 4, except that different pigments and dispersion synergists were used. In the absence of dispersion synergist, a pigment concentration of 5.00 wt% instead of 4.50 wt% was used. Table 4

An ink composition was made by mixing the pigment, the polymeric dispersant Solsperse™ 32000, the dispersion synergist and the organic solvent DEGDEE with a dissolver and subsequently treating this mixture with a roller mill procedure using yttrium-stabilized.zirconium oxide-beads of 0.4 mm diameter ("high wear resistant zirconia grinding media" from TOSOH Co.). A polyethylene flask of 60mL was filled to half its volume with grinding beads and 20 mL of the mixture. The flask was closed with a lit and put on the roller mill for three days. The speed was set at 150 rpm. After milling the dispersion was separated from the beads using a filter cloth.

Poor dispersion stability was observed for the comparative inkjet inks COMP-1 to COMP-10 illustrated by a sharp decrease in SSF and an increase in the particle size of the pigment. On the other hand the inventive inkjet inks INV-1 to INV-10 all exhibited improved dispersion stability.
This example illustrates that the quinacridone derivative can also be advantageously used in radiation curable pigment dispersions and inkjet inks.

heading.u: Preparation and evaluation of pigment dispersions

description.p:
The pigment dispersions were prepared in the same manner to obtain the composition as described in Table 7, except that dispersion synergist was added or not. In the absence of dispersion synergist, a pigment concentration of 5.00 wt% instead of 4.50 wt% was used. Table 7
Wt% of componentDispersion UV-1Dispersion UV-2

The pigment dispersion UV-2 was made by mixing 0.90 g of the pigment PV19/PR202, 3.33 of a 30% solution of the polymeric dispersant Solsperse™ 32000 in DPGDA™, 0.10 g of the dispersion synergist QAD-3 and the rest of the monomer DPGDA™ with a dissolver and subsequently treating this mixture with a roller mill procedure using yttrium-stabilized zirconium oxide-beads of 0.4 mm diameter ("high wear resistant zirconia grinding media" from TOSOH Co.). A polyethylene flask of 60mL was filled to half its volume with grinding beads and 20 mL of the mixture. The flask was closed with a lit and put on the roller mill for three days. The speed was set at 150 rpm. After milling the dispersion was separated from the beads using a filter cloth.

The SSF and the average particle size were determined before and after a heat treatment of 7 days at 80°C to evaluate the dispersion stability. The results are listed in Table 8. Table 8

From Table 8, it is clear that the comparative pigment dispersion UV-1 lacking the dispersion synergist decreased in dispersion quality and stability compared to the inventive dispersion UV-2.

This example illustrates that the quinacridone derivative could also be advantageously used for preparing non-aqueous dispersions of not only diketopyrrolo-pyrrole/quinacridone mixed crystal pigments but also surprisingly of diketopyrrolo-pyrrole pigments (DPP pigments).

heading.u: Preparation and evaluation of a non-aqueous inkjet ink comprising a DPP pigment

description.p:
A milling mixture was prepared with 15 wt% PR254 pigment, 15 wt% polymeric dispersant Solsperse™ 39000 and 1.5 wt% of the quinacridone derivative QAD-3 in DEGDEE as dispersion solvent. The milling mixture was then milled under cooling by a NETZSCH™ LABSTAR1 at a 50 % volume filling with yttrium-stabilized zirconium oxide-beads of 0.4 mm diameter ("high wear resistant zirconia grinding media" from TOSOH Co.) and a residence time of 45 minutes. The prepared dispersion exhibited a viscosityof 23 mPa.s. The inkjet ink INV-11 was prepared to obtain a composition as described in Table 9 by adding 65 parts by weight of DEGDEE to 35 parts by weight of the milling mixture under stirring at room temperature. Table 9
wt% of componentINV-11
PR2545.00

Solsperse™ 390005.00
DEGDEE89.70
The inventive inkjet ink INV-11 exhibited an SSF of 40 and an average particle size of 119 nm.

heading.u: Preparation and evaluation of non-aqueous pigment dispersions comprising a DPP/Quinacridone pigment

description.p:
Two concentrated pigment dispersions were prepared in the same manner to obtain a composition as described in Table 10, except that the dispersion synergist QAD-3 was either present or absent. Table 10
wt% of componentCOMP-11INV-12
DPP/Quinacridone15.0015.00
QAD-3---1.50
Solsperse™ 3900015.0015.00
DEGDEE70.0068.50

A milling mixture was prepared with 15 wt% PR254 pigment, 15 wt% polymeric dispersant Solsperse™ 39000 and optionally 1.5 wt% of the quinacridone derivative QAD-3 in DEGDEE as dispersion solvent. The milling mixture was then milled under cooling by a NETZSCH™ LABSTAR1 at a 50 % volume filling with yttrium-stabilized zirconium oxide-beads of 0.4 mm diameter ("high wear resistant zirconia grinding media" from TOSOH Co.) and a residence time of 45 minutes.
The comparative non-aqueous pigment dispersions COMP-11 exhibited a viscosity of 3821 mPa.s, while the inventive non-aqueous pigment dispersions INV-12 exhibited a viscosity of 29 mPa.s.

This example illustrates that non-aqueous inkjet inks of high dispersion quality and stability can be prepared using a quinacridone derivative in combination with a diketopyrrolo pyrrole pigment. Other pigments, such as Naphtol AS pigments, could not be dispersed by the quinacridone derivative.
description.heading: Preparation and evaluation of a non-aqueous inkjet inks
description.p:
All inkjet inks were prepared in the same manner to obtain a composition as described in Table 11, except that different pigments and dispersion synergists were used. In the absence of dispersion synergist QAD-3, a pigment concentration of 5.00 wt% instead of 4.50 wt% was used. Table 11
Componentwt%
Pigment4.50
QAD-30.50
Solsperse™ 320005.00
DEGDEE90.00

An ink composition was made by mixing the pigment, the polymeric dispersant Solsperse™ 32000, the dispersion synergist and the organic solvent DEGDEE with a dissolver and subsequently treating this mixture with a roller mill procedure using yttrium-stabilized zirconium oxide-beads of 0.4 mm diameter ("high wear resistant zirconia grinding media" from TOSOH Co.). A polyethylene flask of 60 mL was filled to half its volume with grinding beads and 20 mL of the mixture. The flask was closed with a lit and put on the roller mill for three days. The speed was set at 150 rpm. After milling the dispersion was separated from the beads using a filter cloth.
Using the above method, the comparative inkjet inks COMP-12 to COMP-17 and the inventive inkjet inks INV-13 and INV-14 were prepared according to Table 12.
description.heading: Evaluation of inkjet inks
description.p:
The average particle size and the spectral separation factor SSF were determined to evaluate the dispersion quality and were determined again after a heat treatment of 7 days at 80°C. The results are listed in Table 12. Table 12
SamplePigmentQAD-3No heat treatmentAfter 7d/80°C

COMP-15PO71No17711676%164%
COMP-16PR170Yes5721567%11%
COMP-17PR184Yes184520%0%
INV-13PR254Yes10412428%0%
INV-14PO71Yes1211000%0%

Poor dispersion quality and/or stability was observed for the comparative inkjet inks COMP-12 to COMP-17 in the absence of the dispersion synergist or using Naphtol AS pigments. On the other hand the inventive inkjet inks INV-13 and INV-14 exhibited excellent dispersion quality and stability.

claim.claim-text:
Chinacridon-Derivat gemäß Formel (I):
in der R1 und R2 unabhängig voneinander jeweils ein Wasserstoffatom, eine Alkylgruppe oder Halogen bedeuten.

Chinacridon-Derivat nach Anspruch 1, das Formel (II) entspricht :
in der R1 und R2 unabhängig voneinander jeweils ein Wasserstoffatom, eine Alkylgruppe oder Halogen bedeuten.

Chinacridon-Derivat nach Anspruch 1 oder 2, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass die Alkylgruppe aus der Gruppe bestehend aus einer Methylgruppe, einer Ethylgruppe, einer Propylgruppe, einer Isopropylgruppe und Halogen gewählt wird.
Chinacridon-Derivat nach Anspruch 1 oder 2, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass R1 und R2 eine Chlorgruppe bedeuten.
Nicht-wässrige Pigmentdispersion, die ein Chinacridonpigment und ein Chinacridon-Derivat nach einem der Ansprüche 1 bis 4 enthält.

Nicht-wässrige Pigmentdispersion nach Anspruch 5, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass das Chinacridonpigment aus der Gruppe bestehend aus C.I. Pigment Violet 19, C.I. Pigment Red 122, C.I. Pigment Red 202, C.I. Pigment Red 282 und Mischkristallen von Chinacridonpigmenten gewählt wird.
Nicht-wässrige Pigmentdispersion, die ein Diketopyrrol-Pyrrol-Pigment und ein Chinacridon-Derivat nach einem der Ansprüche 1 bis 4 enthält.

Nicht-wässrige Pigmentdispersion nach Anspruch 7, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass das Diketopyrrol-Pyrrol-Pigment aus der Gruppe bestehend aus C.I. Pigment Orange 71, C.I. Pigment Orange 73, C.I. Pigment Orange 81, C.I. Pigment Red 254, C.I. Pigment Red 255, C.I. Pigment Red 264, C.I. Pigment Red 270, C.I. Pigment Red 272 und Mischkristallen von Diketopyrrol-Pyrrol-Pigmenten gewählt wird.
Nicht-wässrige Pigmentdispersion nach einem der Ansprüche 5 bis 8, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass die Pigmentdispersion eine strahlungshärtbare Tintenstrahltinte ist.
Satz nicht-wässriger Tintenstrahltinten, der eine nicht-wässrige Pigmentdispersion nach einem der Ansprüche 5 bis 9 enthält.

Verfahren zur Bildung einer Pigmentdispersion, das folgende Schritte umfasst : (a) Schaffen eines Chinacridon-Derivats nach einem der Ansprüche 1 bis 4, (b) Umwandlung mindestens einer Carbonsäuregruppe des Chinacridon-Derivats in eine Salzgruppe, und (c) Mischen des Chinacridon-Derivats mit einem Pigment in einem Dispersionsmedium.
Verfahren nach Anspruch 11, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass das Salz der mindestens einen Carbonsäuregruppe eine Ammoniumsäuresalzgruppe ist.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 12, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass die Ammoniumsäuresalzgruppe eine substituierte Ammoniumgruppe ist, die aus der Gruppe bestehend aus +N(CH3)2(C18H37)2, +NH(CH3)2(C18H37), +N(CH3)2(C12H25)2, +NH(CH3)2(C12H25), +N(CH3)2(C10H21)2, +NH(CH3)2(C10H21), +N(CH3)2(C8H17)2, +NH(CH3)2(C8H17), +NH(C8H17)3, +NH(C10H21)3, +NH(C12H25)3 und +NH(C18H35)3 gewählt wird.

Verfahren nach einem der Ansprüche 11 bis 13, dadurch gekennzeichnet, dass das Pigment aus der Gruppe bestehend aus C.I. Pigment Violet 19, C.I. Pigment Red 122, C.I. Pigment Red 202, C.I. Pigment Red 209, C.I. Pigment Red 282, Mischkristallen von Chinacridonpigmenten, C.I. Pigment Orange 71, C.I. Pigment Orange 73, C.I. Pigment Orange 81, C.I. Pigment Red 254, C.I. Pigment Red 255, C.I. Pigment Red 264, C.I. Pigment Red 270, C.I. Pigment Red 272 und Mischkristallen von Diketopyrrol-Pyrrol-Pigmenten gewählt wird.

A quinacridone derivative according to Formula (I):
wherein R1 and R2 are each independently selected from the group consisting of hydrogen, alkyl and halogen.

A quinacridone derivative according to claim 1 represented by Formula (II):
wherein R1 and R2 are each independently selected from the group consisting of hydrogen, alkyl and halogen.
The quinacridone derivative according to claim 1 or 2 wherein the alkyl group is selected from the group consisting of methyl, ethyl, propyl, isopropyl and halogen.
The quinacridone derivative according to claim 1 or 2 wherein R1 and R2 represent a chloro group.
A non-aqueous pigment dispersion comprising a quinacridone pigment and a quinacridone derivative according to any one of claims 1 to 4.

The non-aqueous pigment dispersion according to claim 5, wherein said quinacridone pigment is selected from the group consisting of C.I. Pigment Violet 19, C.I. Pigment Red 122, C.I. Pigment Red 202, C.I. Pigment Red 282 and mixed crystals of quinacridone pigments.
A non-aqueous pigment dispersion comprising a diketopyrrolo-pyrrole pigment and a quinacridone derivative according to any one of claims 1 to 4.

The non-aqueous pigment dispersion according to claim 7, wherein said diketopyrrolo-pyrrole pigment is selected from the group consisting of C.I. Pigment Orange 71, C.I. Pigment Orange 73, C.I. Pigment Orange 81, C.I. Pigment Red 254, C.I. Pigment Red 255, C.I. Pigment Red 264, C.I. Pigment Red 270, C.I. Pigment Red 272 and mixed crystals of diketopyrrolo-pyrrole pigments.
The non-aqueous pigment dispersion according to any one of claims 5 to 8 wherein the pigment dispersion is a radiation curable inkjet ink.
A non-aqueous inkjet ink set comprising a non-aqueous pigment dispersion according to any one of claims 5 to 9.

A method for forming a pigment dispersion comprising the steps of: (a) providing a quinacridone derivative according to any of claims 1 to 4; (b) transforming at least one carboxylic acid group of the quinacridone derivative into a salt group; and (c) mixing the quinacridone derivative with a pigment in a dispersion medium.
The method according to claim 11 wherein said salt of the at least one carboxylic acid group is an ammonium acid salt group.

The method according to claim 12 wherein said ammonium acid salt group is a substituted ammonium group selected from the group consisting of +N(CH3)2(C18H37)2, +NH(CH3)2(C18H37), +N(CH3)2(C12H25)2, +NH(CH3)2(C12H25), +N(CH3)2(C10H21)2, +NH(CH3)2(C10H21), +N(CH3)2(C8H17)2, +NH(CH3)2(C8H17), +NH(C8H17)3, +NH(C10H21)3, +NH(C12H25)3 and +NH(C18H35)3.

The method according to any of claims 11 to 13 wherein the pigment is selected from the group consisting of C.I. Pigment Violet 19, C.I. Pigment Red 122, C.I. Pigment Red 202, C.I. Pigment Red 209, C.I. Pigment Red 282, mixed crystals of quinacridone pigments, C.I. Pigment Orange 71, C.I. Pigment Orange 73, C.I. Pigment Orange 81, C.I. Pigment Red 254, C.I. Pigment Red 255, C.I. Pigment Red 264, C.I. Pigment Red 270, C.I. Pigment Red 272 and mixed crystals of diketopyrrolo-pyrrole pigments.

Dérivé de quinacridone selon la Formule (I):
où R1 et R2 représentent chacun, indépendamment l'un de l'autre, un atome d'hydrogène, un groupe alkyle ou de l'halogène.

Dérivé de quinacridone selon la revendication 1 répondant à la Formule (II) :
où R1 et R2 représentent chacun, indépendamment l'un de l'autre, un atome d'hydrogène, un groupe alkyle ou de l'halogène.

Dérivé de quinacridone selon la revendication 1 ou 2, caractérisé en ce que le groupe alkyle est choisi parmi le groupe composé d'un groupe méthyle, d'un groupe éthyle, d'un groupe propyle, d'un groupe isopropyle et d'halogène.
Dérivé de quinacridone selon la revendication 1 ou 2, caractérisé en ce que R1 et R2 représentent un groupe chloro.
Dispersion de pigment non aqueuse contenant un pigment de quinacridone et un dérivé de quinacridone selon l'une quelconque des revendications 1 à 4.

Dispersion de pigment non aqueuse selon la revendication 5, caractérisée en ce que le pigment de quinacridone est choisi parmi le groupe composé de C.I. Pigment Violet 19, C.I. Pigment Red 122, C.I. Pigment Red 202, C.I. Pigment Red 282 et de cristaux mixtes de pigments de quinacridone.
Dispersion de pigment non aqueuse contenant un pigment de dicétopyrrolopyrrole et un dérivé de quinacridone selon l'une quelconque des revendications 1 à 4.

Dispersion de pigment non aqueuse selon la revendication 7, caractérisée en ce que le pigment de dicétopyrrolopyrrole est choisi parmi le groupe composé de C.I. Pigment Orange 71, C.I. Pigment Orange 73, C.I. Pigment Orange 81, C.I. Pigment Red 254, C.I. Pigment Red 255, C.I. Pigment Red 264, C.I. Pigment Red 270, C.I. Pigment Red 272 et de cristaux mixtes de pigments de dicétopyrrolopyrrole.

Dispersion de pigment non aqueuse selon l'une quelconque des revendications 5 à 8, caractérisée en ce que la dispersion de pigment est une encre pour impression à jet d'encre durcissable par rayonnement.
Ensemble d'encres pour impression à jet d'encre non aqueuses comprenant une dispersion de pigment non aqueuse selon l'une quelconque des revendications 5 à 9.

Procédé pour la préparation d'une dispersion de pigment, comprenant les étapes consistant à : (a) mettre à disposition un dérivé de quinacridone selon l'une quelconque des revendications 1 à 4, (b) convertir au moins un groupe acide carboxylique du dérivé de quinacridone en un groupe sel, et (c) mélanger le dérivé de quinacridone avec un pigment dans un milieu de dispersion.
Procédé selon la revendication 11, caractérisé en ce que le sel dudit au moins un groupe acide carboxylique est un groupe sel d'acide d'ammonium.

Procédé selon la revendication 12, caractérisé en ce que le groupe sel d'acide d'ammonium est un groupe ammonium substitué qui est choisi parmi le groupe composé de +N(CH3)2(C18H37)2, +NH(CH3)2(C18H37), +N(CH3)2(C12H25)2, +NH(CH3)2(C12H21), +N(CH3)2(C10H21)2, +NH(CH3)2(C10H21), +N(CH3)2(C8H17)2, +NH(CH3)2(C8H17). +NH(C8H17)3, +NH(C10H21)3, +NH(C12H25)3 et +NH(C18H35)3.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications 11 à 13, caractérisé en ce que le pigment est choisi parmi le groupe composé de C.I. Pigment Violet 19, C.I. Pigment Red 122, C.I. Pigment Red 202, C.I. Pigment Red 209, C.I. Pigment Red 282, de cristaux mixtes de pigments de quinacridone, C.I. Pigment Orange 71, C.I. Pigment Orange 73, C.I. Pigment Orange 81, C.I. Pigment Red 254, C.I. Pigment Red 255, C.I. Pigment Red 264, C.I. Pigment Red 270, C.I. Pigment Red 272 et de cristaux mixtes de pigments de dicétopyrrolopyrrole.
